the hacked material appeared to have been disseminated through users of 4Chan, an online bulletin board. 47 million registered voters seems low at this point, considering how hot this election is  (even though this time 2012, second round registered was 43 million, first round was @46 million). I think there will be more abstainers which help Le Pen 5+ Email hacking - a case could be made that Macron's campaign managers did this as a disinformation strategy to help Macron win (or help MLP lose). (A case could be made that the explosion a week before the first round helped MLP) I wouldn't put anything past anyone these days.  5+ Feel that the press is very one-sided in coverage (similar to coverage during trump campaign) and limiting coverage of MLP, and angling stories to create positive coverage for Macron. I read the comments in (English) newspapers and there are quite a few anti-macron/holland/globalization ones 5+ -Email hacking as disinformation from Macron/LP camps: "thousands of emails" is actually not that much. For instance my own gmail account (20+years old) only has 1.3 GB used. I think I store email very sparingly so my 1.3 Gigs might be l less than the average person's. A news snippet said 9 GB of info were hacked and released. This could equal anywhere from 1 person's work/campaign email system, to say, 10 people (unlikely to be as high as say 100, 50 or even 20 people's accounts.)  Also fact that France was on "high alert after 2016" against precisely this sort of attack makes me wonder how the hackers did this. (WSJ).  We must remember, other than Macron's press release, we have no proof yet there has even been a hack. Third, timing of hack, right when news blackout hit means it's all rumour as to what was hacked; who did it; what the hack contains, how damaging it may or may not be. (If it turns out the hack revealed very little damaging info for Macron, then my suspicions would be greatly heightened) - none of it can be actually be scrutinized until after the election, so really, then what was the point? Fourth, the blackout rules were public knowledge. The parties especially very well knew these rules. If MLP did this, then she must have been aware all fingers would automatically be pointed to her so how would it benefit her - more seems to hurt her campaign.  The question is, while MLP voters would be suspicious of the email hack, would Macron voters be? I think likely they would be because they are not very sticky towards him. More likely, that they would question this just as I am questioning and wonder how would it help Le Pen. This is unlike the Hilary voters who were very sticky towards her and failed to notice the negative impact of things like the unsecured server (which wasn't really a crime). Really hope I'm wrong.

Taking in account the voters who will abstain or hold their nose and vote LePen also recent banking allegations of Macron, true or no. Email hack release so late in game possible lead in for excuse of "surprise" loss. Le Pen win will be slightly higher than 50% but not above 52.

The Macron team is the victim of an IT attack, the Control Commission will meet Friday night, several gigas of internal documents (mails, accounting documents ...) of the Macron team were published on the social networks, via a link diffused by the site WikiLeaks, and abundantly relayed by the extreme right on Twitter . WikiLeaks assured it was not the origin of this operation which it called "MacronLeaks". At 23:56, 4 minutes before the end of the campaign, the candidate's team denounced a "massive and coordinated piracy action", seeing it as a "destabilization operation" on the eve of the second round. "Those who circulate these documents add to the authentic documents a lot of false documents, in order to sow doubt and misinformation," said the Macron team. These files are pirated and disseminated "on social networks" are "internal" information in Emmanuel Macron's campaign like e-mails or "accounting documents", and are all "legal", added En Marche !. The National Commission for the Control of the Presidential Campaign recommended to the media "not to account for the content" of the internal data resulting from this "computer attack", recalling that "the spreading of false information is liable to fall under the law". The Commission states that it will meet in the next few hours.

The BBC’s aggregate poll claims that about 18% of people polled have not expressed a preference for either of the candidates. Of the remaining 82%, there is a 59/41 split in favour of Macron [1], so:  Macron: 0.82 * 0.59 = 48%
Le Pen: 0.82 * 0.41 = 34%
Undecided: 18% However, the Ipsos poll includes an average confidence estimate (presumably people were asked to estimate how certain they were about their choice) [2]. Confidence is 91% for Macron voters, 88% for Le Pen voters, and 51% for undecided voters (ie, confident that they won’t vote at all). So, taking the word “certain” with a pinch of salt: Macron certain: 0.48 * 0.91 = 44%
Macron uncertain: 48 - 44 = 4%
Le Pen certain: 0.34 * 0.88 = 30%
Le Pen uncertain: 34 - 30 = 4%
Undecided certain: 9%
Undecided uncertain: 9% Maybe the uncertain ones will split equally between the three options: Macron: 0.44 + (0.04 * 0.33) + (0.04 * 0.33) + (0.09 * 0.33) = 50%
Le Pen: 0.3 + (0.04 * 0.33) + (0.04 * 0.33) + (0.09 * 0.33) = 36%
Actual abstainers: 100 - 50 - 36 = 14% Turnout is historically very high in the second round [3]; the average for the three most recent elections is 81%. However, the public holiday and the apparent apathy reported in the mood of voters might make it a bit lower (the weather forecast looks reasonably OK, btw). If we say 76% turnout then that would add 10% to the “actual abstainers” above; I’d be inclined to subtract most of these from Macron - his voters would probably be the more apathetic given his lead in the polls: Macron: 50% - 7% = 43%
Le Pen: 36% - 3% = 33%
Abstain: 24% Having tried to take a few things into account, that 10% gap does seem rather a lot to catch up, even given inaccuracy of polls, the “shy tory factor” [4], etc. On that basis, I’d put my own confidence at 90% in favour of Macron. [1] http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-39801315
[2] http://www.ipsos.fr/presidentielle2017/
[3] http://www.euronews.com/2017/04/21/a-history-of-french-presidential-elections-through-nine-infographics
[4] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shy_Tory_Factor

The debate seems to have been in favour of Macron who increases his lead in the polls to 61%. An interesting piece from The Independent: Headline: "Undecided voters and 'shy FN' supporters could win the French election for Marine Le Pen" http://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/marine-le-pen-french-election-front-national-emmanuel-macron-second-round-voting-results-a7714006.html The dilemma of the voters is presented as being undecided between a spoiled vote and a vote for Macron, but the article hints that there is some significant support for Le Pen among Fillon voters - which in my opinion should surprise no one.

Melenchon voters don't seem to be terribly enthusiastic for Macron. This article says that most Melenchon supporters will abstain: "Two-thirds of French far-left supporters won't vote for Macron" https://www.thelocal.fr/20170502/two-thirds-of-french-far-left-supporters-wont-vote-for-macron Here's a quote: " Out of some 243, 000 members polled, 36.1 percent said they intend to cast a blank ballot. Another 29 percent said they would abstain while the remaining 34.8 percent said they will vote for Emmanuel Macron. Voting for the far right Marine Le Pen was not included as an option." It might have been interesting to include a vote for Le Pen as an option. There are at least two  possible reasons for excluding that choice: 1) the authors of the survey thought the number would be statistically insignificant, and therefore did not need to be recorded; 2) the authors of the survey thought the number of Le pen voters among Melenchon supporters might be embarrassingly high. Whatever the case, because the option for Le Pen was excluded, the survey doesn't give a reliable picture of the intentions of Melenchon voters; a Melenchon supporter who intends to vote for Le Pen might not have completed the survey, since his or her preferred option was not included, and the voter would have been unable to give accurate information about his/her intentions.

Still not sure which way this is going to go. In a sense Le Pen has been setting the agenda for years - and some of the issues she raises - integration of Muslims and the increasingly pernicious threat of Islamic terrorism, and the unaccountability and anti-democratic nature of the EU - are of fundamental importance.  And most mainstream polticians are reluctant to touch these topics with a bargepole - despite the omniscience of armed soldiers on the streets ,a prolonged state of emergency, and hundreds of deaths;  not to mention the economic consequences of the country having sacrificed many areas of financial and economic policy on the altar of the supremely ill-thought-through menace of the Euro.....and the perpetually high unemployment, especially among the young, that has proved very difficult to do anything about. However, her attempts to clean-up the image of the FN have only been partial - and their shortcomings have been made quite blatant in recent weeks. First, her very ambiguous comment - reaching for plausible deniability on one hand - and for the traditional (pre-Chirac) Gaullist line on the on the other - about French culpability for the deporatation of Jews form Paris in WW2 - is a clear black mark against her. And then her interim replacement as Party leader had to step down very quickly after a similar bit of holocaust minimisation. Very much in the fashion of Jean Marie Le Pen - who his daughter has been courage and principled to stand up to..... but, still, today, in May Day FN rallies in Paris, it is still Jean-Marie who has the pride of place..... That will all count against her. As will the sense that she is constantly angry, and that her demeanour is one of someone who is constantly angry. Maybe this will not count for so much - Sarkozy was hardly "presidential" in a traditional sense, and nor really (but for different reasons) has been Hollande. What will count for her? Gaining votes from supporters of one of the other main EU-sceptic candidates, Nicolas Dupont-Aignan, who she has pledged to appoint as PM - but at just under 5% of the 1st round vote, that is no big deal. The support of those who voted for the far-leftist Melenchon, with nearly 20%, would be a bigger prize -   but he has increasingly shifted his stance of being, effectitvely, pro-abstention, to make it clear that he regards Le Pen as a more unacceptable candidate than Fillon. And looking at where Melenchon obtained most support (above all the highly multi-ethnic Seine-Saint-Denis, which is not obvious FN territory), it seems increasingly unlikely that many of his supporters will switch to Le Pen in round 2.  Maybe some Gaullist/"Republicans" might, but probably not in very large numbers. In a sense this round is Macron's to lose.  I'm not sure he is in tune with the mood of France, I'm not sure that his eulogies to the EU and to liberal economics (which he would surely, in practice, be unable to enforce) don't repel more voters than they attract. And I don't know how far the legendary "republican front" against the FN can hold up, as it did - against a far more overtly repulsive FN figure - in 2002 - or in more recent regional elections.  In theory it should hold up - but really, unless Macron manages to implement substantive economic liberalisation and other social reforms, he is surely on the road to nowhere in the longer term.... If Marine Le Pen is seeking to win the next election in 2022 she would need to further rebrand her party and attract more mainstream Gaullists to her side - and make sure the party is less of a family affair, too, as well as less tainted with the legacy of fascism. (I think the first of these things will be - far -  more difficult to achieve, although the problems of the latter shouldn't be underestimated either). Macron's main areas of support are that he is backed by a substantial part of the (still not entirely insignificant - in terms of organizaton on the ground ) Socialist Party, and by probably a majority of Gaullists. Plus by others who consider themselves anti-fascists who regard Le Pen, still, as such. For now though - even if she has set the general direction and tone, Le Pen has more hurdles to overcome than does Macron. It'd be foolish to rule out her winning: France has a history of sudden, extreme, revolutionary changes rather than gradual evolutions. But it still seems unlikely that her support will be greater than the resistance against her, at least for now.

Let us accept that the polls give a correct estimate of voter's intentions. Then the second round will be determined by the turnout. A high support in the polls (let's say 60%) for Macron, but a low turnout (let's say 60%) could still mean that Le Pen (support = 40%, but turnout = 95%) wins. Complacency and/or lukewarm support for Macron from his former adversaries could reduce his turnout, while the small chance to win against all odds could bolster the Le Pen turnout. However: the calculations show that, given the present polling results (http://www.linternaute.com/actualite/politique/1357555-presidentielle-2017-resultat-dernier-sondage-macron-le-pen-2eme-tour) (Macron = 60,5% and Le Pen =39,5%) that Macron would win once his turnout is 62,5% or above. On average he will win 84,8% of all simulations in which his turnout goes from 55% to 75%, and the Le Pen turnout goes from 75% to 95%. If we only accept a "sure win" when 85% of the simulations go to one candidate, then Macron has a  ''sure win" in 70% of the simulations. Probably a bit conservative.

I don't think integration has been positive in France. +++
*Russia rumour-mongering helps Le Pen +

She is cleaning up or sweetening this part of history. It very likely will work on certain people at a certain point in their life. (Hitler was voted into power in increments after all) Macron should be a powerful oppositional voice here - rallying his supporters with an emotional appeal at watershed moment in French and European history. But I think, he is too scared, too much of a yes-man to even broach the subject. +++ On the plus side (why she might lose):

A debate over Le Pen's chances between The Economist and Ian Bremmer and Charles Lichfield of the Eurasia Group: http://www.economist.com/blogs/graphicdetail/2017/04/france-s-presidential-election Here's a quote that addresses a question that @GTS666 asked below: "During the past six presidential elections, the average prediction of run-off polls taken just before the first round has missed the actual second-round result by a mere three percentage points. In 2012, pre-first-round surveys gave François Hollande around 54% of the run-off vote against Nicolas Sarkozy; he wound up getting 52%. Five years earlier, they foresaw Mr Sarkozy’s 53% to 47% victory over Ségolène Royal to within a single percentage point. And of course, run-off polls in 2002 had Jacques Chirac crushing Ms Le Pen’s father Jean-Marie by 78% to 22%; Mr Chirac actually received 82%." So previous pre-runoff polls have apparently been very accurate in predicting the ultimate winner. But since The Economist provides no details about undecideds on non-responders, I don't know how much that track record applies to this election. Here's another quote that in my opinion succinctly sums up two approaches to forecasting that we find on GJO: "At the same time, just because polls can’t tell you everything doesn’t mean they don’t tell you anything. Given that Eurasia Group has published a quantitative prediction of Ms Le Pen’s chances at 40%, one might assume they had deployed a quantitative methodology to produce it. However, the assessment by Mr Bremmer and Mr Lichfield contains nary a mention of the ample polling figures available. The only data they cite—without providing specific numbers—is their evaluation of comparative enthusiasm for the candidates on social media, which they say favours Ms Le Pen over Mr Macron. That’s intriguing, and we would be eager to see statistical evidence based on past French elections showing that data regarding social-media platforms—which were already well-established during the 2012 presidential campaign—contributes additional, relevant information on top of polling and yields more accurate predictions." So it comes down to the difference between forecasting based on what the numbers say, and forecasting on the basis of how people behave, and what motivates given sets of voters. We'll see which approach pays off this time.

Some more polling, for what it's worth: https://www.bloomberg.com/politics/articles/2017-04-04/macron-would-be-second-choice-for-le-pen-voters-in-french-ballot The headline is: "Macron Would Be Second Choice for Le Pen Voters in French Ballot" Which I frankly don't believe, but who knows? Perhaps the most interesting part of the article is at the very end: "Ifop also asked directly who supporters of candidates defeated in the first round would vote for in the runoff. Among Fillon supporters, 37 percent broke for Macron with 32 percent for Le Pen, while 31 percent wouldn’t answer. Among Melenchon supporters, 48 percent said Macron, 9 percent Le Pen, and 43 percent had no answer. Hamon voters would go 71 percent for Macron, 3 percent Le Pen, and 26 percent declined to say." So 26% of Hamon voters won't answer who they'll vote for in the runoff, along with 31% of Fillon supporters , and 43% of Melenchon voters. I interpret this as meaning that these people do not categorically rule out voting for Le Pen. These numbers may be way off, I may be wrong in how I interpret them, and even if I'm right that may change after Sunday. But if these numbers do reflect actual voter sentiment I think it's noteworthy. It also makes me wonder about people who have declared that they're undecided about the vote on Sunday, and who they will wind up voting for in the runoff.

You know what?  On reflection, given the latest poll numbers, the runoff set is a four-way mathematical dead heat.  So: 1) Le Pen would lose to anyone but Melenchon in a runoff, which might give them as much as a 50-50 chance.  50% chance of NF making runoff, 33.3% chance of being paired with Socialist, 50% chance of victory over Socialist, so 8% chance or so of victory. 2) Melenchon would lose to Marcon in a runoff certainly, to Fillon most likely, and maybe-maybe-not to Le Pen.  So 50%*33.333%*10% for Fillon matchup, 50%*33.3333%*50% for Le Pen, 10% chance of victory. 3) Fillon beats Le Pen, probably beats Melenchon, and is moderately disadvantaged against Marcon.  50%*33.33%*100% for Le Pen, 50%*33.333%*90% for Melenchon, 50%*33.333%*40% for Marcon,  4) Marcon beats Le Pen or Melenchon (so 50%*66.666%*100%), moderately advantaged against Fillon (50%*33.33333%*60%). There is something very worrying about the polls for the French presidential elections. Most polls have a sample size of about 1000 to 2000. A 95% confidence interval is then +-2%. However, when you look at the different polls the differences in the results for almost all candidates is less than 1%. This could mean that all pollsters use the same stratification method when they construct their sample. That could make them all biased in the same way. Looking at the polls of the presidential elections of 2012 we find the same, unlikely, concentration of the poll results from different pollsters. Comparing the polls with the results of the first round in 2012 we see that polls and results were almost exact for the two leading candidates (Hollande and Sarkozy), but Le Pen scored 2% higher and Mélenchon 2% lower. But in 2012 the leading candidates were about 10% in front of the other two. This is not the case now. All have polls around 20%. A second round between Macron and Le Pen is slightly the most likely, but it should not be a ''stunning" surprise if Fillon and Mélenchon are the winners of the first round.

Unprecedented and confusing since the beginning, the 2017 presidential campaign will remain so until the end. Ten days before the first round of voting, on Sunday 23 April, we have been in an unprecedented situation for half a century: four candidates - François Fillon, Marine Le Pen, Emmanuel Macron and Jean-Luc Mélenchon - To qualify for the second round.
The indecision of voters
All the investigations have been testifying for weeks. The level of indecision of the French is clearly higher than in the previous presidential elections, except for 2002. Currently, only two-thirds (66%) intend to vote on 23 April. The temptation of abstention particularly affects the youngest voters: 55% of 18-24 year olds intend to vote, 60% of 25-34 year olds. While almost three-quarters of those over 70 years of age say they will vote. This level of indecision has not decreased since Ipsos' previous survey, conducted a week earlier. Weary voters may not feel it, but the official French presidential campaign starts only today, ahead of first-round voting on April 23rd. Posters will go up on formal municipal hoardings in every town. All 11 candidates henceforth gain equal airtime. This will be quite a challenge: they include an anti-capitalist Ford factory worker, a Trotskyist high-school teacher and a centrist ex-shepherd. Among the five front-runners, opinion polls have for weeks made the far-right Marine Le Pen and the centrist Emmanuel Macron favourites for the run-off on May 7th. But pollsters have been wrong a lot recently (Trump, Brexit), the share of undecided voters is high and last-minute surges or tactical voting cannot be ruled out. Already, the far-left Jean-Luc Mélenchon has overtaken the Socialists’ Benoît Hamon. He could yet snatch third place from the conservative François Fillon. A race already marked by surprises may have more in store

But the question is pertinent to French national identity, and therefore to the election: is the real France the Vichy regime, or is the real France De Gaulle's Free France? Le Pen appears to be staking out the traditional postwar Gaullist turf, and it remains to be seen if a) she winds up the only candidate who is able to claim the mantle of the "national epic," and b) if this makes a difference. For those forecasters whose forecasts follow the polls: "Macron's lead narrows in French presidential election: Polls" http://www.cnbc.com/2017/04/06/macrons-lead-narrows-in-french-presidential-election-polls.html Macron is down 3 points in the runoff! Is this a trend? A harbinger of things to come? How many more 3-point drops can he take before he's no longer a viable candidate? Has his candidacy imploded? What does it all mean? Actually, it means absolutely nothing. At this stage, the only polls that matter are those that predict the vote for the April 23 preliminary round. It is only after the first round ends that the second round polls will begin to take their final shape. In my opinion, the thing to watch for in polls between April 23 and the runoff is the number of undecided voters. If there are enough undecided voters to give Le Pen a win, it means that her "extremist" views are not considered all that extremist, and a significant number of voters regard her as an acceptable candidate - and presumably acceptable president. A large number of undecideds after April 23 doesn't mean that she'll win, but it will mean that the prospect of her winning cannot be dismissed out of hand. It means that there will almost certainly not be any development of a "Republican Front" of the kind that defeated her father 15 years ago, and the election will be much closer than the current polls would indicate.

The most likely scenario is a Macron/Le Pen run-off. Recent history suggests that the run-off follows the first round, except when one candidate is an extremist, like Le Pen, in which case support rallies around the other candidate. Of the other options, Melenchon seems to be moving upwards and, although not especially likely to win, he increases the chances of 'None of the above'. Fillon is going nowhere in the polls even after a good debate so seems unlikely to make the jump. Hamon is going backwards.

Centrist Emmanuel Macron is projected to come out on top in the first round of France's presidential election next month ahead of far-right leader Marine Le Pen before going on to win in a runoff, a Harris Interactive poll showed on Thursday. Macron was seen winning 26 percent of the vote in the April 23 first round followed by Le Pen on 25 percent, according to the poll for France Televisions. Both scores were unchanged from the last time the poll was carried out two weeks ago, even though it was carried out after the two traded barbs in a televised debate on Monday involving all the main candidates. Conservative candidate Francois Fillon saw his score slip to 18 percent of the first round vote from 20 percent as he struggles to limit the damage from a series of financial scandals. Meanwhile, far-left candidate Jean-Luc Melenchon saw his share of the vote rise to 13.5 percent, surpassing for the first time the score for the ruling Socialists candidate Benoit Hamon at 12.5 percent. Macron was seen winning the presidency by beating Le Pen in the May 7 runoff with 65 percent of the vote to 35 percent for the National Front leader, unchanged from two weeks ago. The poll was conducted on March 21-22 among 6,383 voters.

Like the forecasting on the 2016 U.S. election, much of what we see here pertains to polls, prediction markets, and bookmakers, and very little addresses issues and the respective candidates’ policies on them. The U.S. and French electoral systems are quite different, but I think this is beside the point. Whatever dissimilarities there are, both systems rely on people voting in order to determine a winner. So the questions are, who will vote for which candidate, and for what reasons? I think the main issues in the French election will be immigration and terrorism. In fact, I think these will effectively be the only issues. Reading Macron’s manifesto yesterday – or more accurately, reading several English-language synopses – I find that he barely broached these subjects at all. He provided some boilerplate about more police, increased incarceration, and increasing the defense budget. The rest of his manifesto was about spending, jobs, and government reform. It seems to me likely that for most French voters, what is important is being able to go to Bastille Day fireworks without someone plowing a truck through the crowd, or attending a concert without someone spraying the venue with automatic rifle fire, or being able to attend Mass without someone beheading the priest. The presence of foreigners in many of France’s cities is probably pretty alarming, and I would think that French voters do not see any reason why they should allow the influx to continue. Macron has said that we are in an age of migrations, and that these migrations are unstoppable. I imagine that most voters regard the current migrations as the result of policies pursued by their governments, and believe that those policies can be reversed if the politicians in power have the will to reverse them. I also believe that they will vote based on that premise, and not on the premise that the migrations are a force of nature outside of human agency. Macron has praised Chancellor Merkel’s immigration policy, and talked about “European values.” But “European values” is an abstraction, and a contentious one at that. He is asking for the votes of French men and women; abstractions don’t vote. And the people whose votes Macron is asking for probably don’t think there’s much to admire about Merkel’s immigration policy. The voters are probably much more concerned about their own personal safety, their national identity, and their country’s civil peace than they are about “European values” as defined by professional politicians, journalists, and NGOs.  I think the voters will probably regard themselves as the inheritors of, and defenders of, France, which is a real place, with a real history, and a real culture that distinguishes its people from other people. I think the voters’ French identity will supersede any European identity that Macron and the political class wants to appeal to. I doubt if Macron has any appeal for working and middle class French men and women. Moreover, I believe this is true even of the hard Left; trade unionists have no reason to support mass immigration, and they have no reason to exempt Islam from their anti-clericalism. They have no reason to support Macron, who has nothing in common with working people, and seems not to offer anything to them beyond platitudes. If the contest is between Macron and Le Pen, I believe that Leftists will vote for Le Pen as an expression of both their national and class identities. Macron is an investment banker by profession. Champion of the working class is a hard sell for him.  What it comes down to, in my opinion, is that a majority of French voters have no positive reason the vote for Macron. Despite his supposed “outsider” credentials, if you are a union member, or a small business person, or unemployed, or in any way just an ordinary person, he is an insider – again, an investment banker, and former government official. There is no reason to think, from anything that Macron has said, that he’s on the side of ordinary people, or that their priorities are his. Finally, this is not 2002. Jean-Marie Le Pen did not run for president after two years of increasingly horrific terrorist attacks, and an inundation of refugees. The circumstances are quite different for Marine Le Pen, and the issues that her father ran on probably have much more resonance today than they did fifteen years ago.

This election is not even remotely similar to the US presidential election or the Brexit referendum:
a) Le Pen is not an unknown quantity. The Front National has been a consistent player in French politics for a long time and hence polling agencies have been able to fine-tune their models.
b) Both in the US and the UK the polls were actually quite narrow and the final results arguably in the expected margins of error (which made some of the forecasts particularly ludicrous).
c) Le Pen will need >50% of votes to win the election, either in the first or potentially in the second round. She is currently polling at around 26%. There are of course some scenarios that could see a Le Pen win, especially when running against Fillon: e.g. turnout and the breaking of major news involving Fillon during round one and round 2.

In light of the fact that the strategy underpinning the attacks is to turn French society against it's Muslim citizens, it can be supposed that a signinificant attack is due in advance of the elections, with the aim of promoting support for Le Pen. Therefore, assuming a major attack takes place before the French elections, the chances of a Le Pen victory rise noticeably. The question may lay in the timing and number of attacks. In sum, in the absence of an attack, Le Pen is a contender but may not pull off a victory. But following an attack, her chances increase noticeably. First Forecast, as always without too much additional background but here are some thoughts
1. 2 round system makes it hard for insurgent candidates to win
    - in 2002 when Jean Marie LePen won in the first round he was trounced by Chirac in the second round as supporters of other parties rallied around Chirac to defeat Lepen
   - something similar happened in 2015 where FN candidates were defeated in regional elections after making it to the second round when voters rallied around establishment party candidates

Macron is keeping his lead and the Republicans are on the decline. There is a fair chance for him to peel a few percentage points from the Juppe Republicans (socially moderate), and from the moderate Socialists (not enamored by the Hamon/Melenchon tales).  Those who write off Le Pen, be aware - she has a well-defined program (which Macron doesn't) and is able to tap into the primal feelings of fear from foreigners and anger against the elites. Also, there is probably a hidden vote for Le Pen, not expressed in the polls. Sound familiar?  I still keep 10 percent for the Republicans - the difference between Fillon and Macron is not that large, and suppose Fillon apologizes deeply for the mistake, returns the money, and asks for forgiveness. His electorate may find it in its heart to do just that. A replacement Republican wouldn't do very well, on the other hand. Following @Xu, also: 
Improving election prediction internationally
Science 355 (6324), 515-520. [doi: 10.1126/science.aal2887]
Ryan Kennedy, Stefan Wojcik and David Lazer (February 2, 2017) Editor's summary:
Using global data for election predictions
Assumptions underlying election result predictions have been questioned recently. Kennedy et al. assessed more than 650 executive office elections in over 85 countries and performed two live forecasting experiments. They analyzed a variety of potential predictors theorized to be of importance, ranging from economic performance to polling data. Elections were about 80 to 90% predictable, despite uncertainties with available data. Polling data were very important to successful prediction, although it was necessary to correct for systematic biases. Unexpectedly, economic indicators were only weakly predictive. As data sources improve and grow, predictive power is expected to increase.

Last week, France’s Les Républicains had an American Republican moment — namely, they relived Richard Nixon’s televised 1952 Checkers speech. Just as the U.S. vice presidential candidate responded to charges that he and his family had dipped into a political campaign fund, so too did François Fillon, the French Républicains’ presidential candidate, appear on television to defend himself against similar charges. Nixon’s gamble paid off. His remark that his wife, Pat, wore a “respectable Republican cloth coat” instead of mink won over enough Republican voters to salvage his place on Dwight Eisenhower’s ticket. Whether Fillon’s will do the same remains to be seen. He faces greater odds. As the satirical and investigative weekly Le Canard Enchaîné revealed last Wednesday, Fillon had funneled enough money — about $540,000 — from his taxpayer-funded parliamentary account into his wife’s private bank account for her to buy plenty of fur, should she so choose. One week later, the news got worse: turns out, according to Canard, the figure was closer to $900,000.

The European Parliament is set to halve French far-right presidential candidate Marine Le Pen’s salary after she missed a deadline to repay allegedly misspent funds.

Interesting article from the New York Times. The author tries to address all of Europe, but keeps circling back to France: https://www.nytimes.com/2017/01/22/world/europe/france-left-socialist-primary.html?_r=0 The piece ends with a quote from a French entrepreneur who does business internationally and supports Macron. Quote: “I have the impression that a good part of the establishment lives wearing the spectacles of the 20th century,” he said. He added that politicians were manipulating the picture so that “in the working-class neighborhoods, there has been a sense of abandonment that pushes people into the arms of the National Front.” “The world has changed,” he said, “and a certain number of people do not want to see that.” End quote. It could be argued that one example of "wearing the spectacles of the 20th century" is embracing the idea that the most dangerous problem facing Europe is the possibility of the development of rival alliance blocs led by France and Germany. It's just possible that the problems facing Europe today are quite different. And of course, the idea of the nation-state has been the organizing principle of the French polity since Louis XIV, if not earlier. In France, the idea of the French nation long predates the 20th century. And sometimes people feel "a sense of abandonment" not because they are being manipulated into feeling that, but because they actually have been abandoned.  But the gentleman is right; the world is changing, although he may find that it is changing in a way that he doesn't find all that satisfying.

This means that it is very probable that Hamon will be the official PS-candidate. This is good news for Emmanuel Macron, because Hamon is much more to the left of him then Valls. The non-radical left could choose him to prevent a guaranteed fight for the presedency between the (very) right (Fillon) and the ultra-right (Le Pen). There is no news about the position of Bayrou. Revised following round one of Socialist Primary. A left leaning candidate (Hamon) seems to have won this round and the right leaning candidate seems to have got about 30% of the votes, meaning that around 70% of the primary voters chose the more extremist left wingers. Its reasonable to assume that Hamon will pick up these extreme left votes in the second round. Which will mean Hamon is the official Socialist Candidate. The turnout for the primary was low which reflects that the French left has lost its enthusiasm and presumably does not believe its likely that a Socialist will win the Presidency election. 
However in the polls left wing candidates (socialists in outlook) are supported by about as many voters (about 25%) as the far right FN (26%), the right Republicans (27%) and the centre (21%). The difference is that support on the left is divided between the Socialist Party itself and several individuals and small parties. According to the current polls the FG party of Melenchon (15%) is more popular than the official Socialist Party (about 10%) neither are thought to have any realistic chance of winning, or of even getting into the second round. In the 2012 election Melenchon's support drifted down from 17% to 11% by election day (presumably because his supporters gave him no chance of winning and wanted to vote for the least bad candidate who had a chance of winning.) But in 2012 they had the choice of switching to an official Socialist who had a good chance of winning (and who did win), but in 2017 there is no Socialist who appears to have any chance of winning. So what will left wing voters do? 
Option A would be for all left wing supporters to support one candidate. It seems too late for that option.
Option B would be for left wing supporters to stick to voting for candidates who have no hope of winning, which is likely to guarantee that the next President is either from the Right or the Far Right. Presumably most left wingers would not want that, although some "left behind" voters wanting a revolution might be tempted to switch to Le Pen. In the past second round voting after the left wing candidates had been eliminated has not shown evidence of left wing voters switching to FN.
Option C  would be for the tactical voting to start in the first round (as appeared to happen in 2012, when Melenchon's support faded). In this case its would seem possible that supporters for left wing candidates start looking for the least bad (as they see it) of the three main candidates.  There are more than 25% of voters who favour the left. It seems entirely possible that a quarter or more of them could switch to Macron as being less right  wing than Fillon or Le Pen. Although a few revolutionary minded left wing voters could switch to Le Pen I doubt that many left wing supporters would switch to Fillon. So I see the first round going to any two of Le Pen, Fillon or Macron, with the second round going to Fillon or Macron.  If the first round goes to Le Pen and Fillon then the second round is likely to go to Fillon. If the first round goes to Le Pen and Macron then the second round would likely go to Macron. If the first round goes to Fillon and Macron then the second round would likely go to Macron. So on that basis its 2 out of 3 chances to Macron. But there is still a greater chance of Fillon getting to the second round that Macron.

Hamon vs Valls in second round for the Socialists. Montebourg asks his supporters to vote for Hamon in the second round. Hamon, a more left-leaning socialist than Valls, will most likely win, which will help Macron.

As the actual candidates are becoming clearer I have revised my forecast slightly. We now know that Hollande is not going to be the Socialist candidate, which raises their chances a little. The polls have consistently shown the Republicans to be the most popular party  ahead of the Front National by 4 to 6 percent in the first round and the Republicans opening up this lead to up to 30% in the latest 2 nd round polls. The FN seems to attract no additional votes between the first and second rounds and no poll shows over 45% for the FN and most polls have the FN at around 33% to 40%. The campaigns have not yet started so It could change. There is no sign in the polls of the surprising Brexit vote or the election of Trump affecting the mood in France. This is surprising as the English language media have made a lot of the idea that there is a swing to the populist right throughout Europe. One might have expected that disillusioned Socialists would switch to the FN, in the same way that Trump has picked up votes from left behind Democrats, and that the media claims are UK Labour voters switching to UKIP. The French polls show no such move. In fact Le Pen's best polling figures seem to have been in 2014 and 2015, and are lower now. Maybe the UK Brexit supporters are just indulging in wishful thinking believing that most countries in the EU are going to vote for right wing populist parties. Austria's re-run Presidential election showed a clear swing away from the Populist candidate between the May vote and December vote,  opening up a 7% lead for the non-Populist winner. Maybe the European Populist tide has passed its high water mark; voters have made their protest and seen no obvious improvements. I doubt that many EU voters see the Brexit vote in the UK has brought any benefits. The latest polls show that only 39% of employees in the UK expect the UK Government to be able to negotiate a good Brexit deal - not a great endorsement of the idea of leaving the EU. As the FN wants to hold a referendum of France leaving the EU the lack of progress in the UK on Brexit would not be an encouragement (and Frexit would be far more difficult that Brexit, as France would presumably need to figure out how to leave the Euro as well).

The French Presidential election is a two round voting system [1]. Opinion polls showed that the Republicans led by a slight margin the National Front, approximately 27% and 25% respectively. The Socialists were lagging behind at approximately 12% [2]. Opinion polls for the second round Fillon vs Le Pen showed roughly double the likelihood of a Republican victory. This means that National Front will do well enough in the first round to make it to the second round, and then FN will be defeated by a high margin. This is what happened in the 2002 French presidential elections. An analysis by Express reached the same conclusions [3]. This forecast has a higher probability difference between the Republicans and the National Front than the consensus, which reduced the gap in December, perhaps influenced by Trump's win. In answering this question, one should consider both the economic and social/cultural dimension. Fillon is actually politically vulnerable in both dimensions. Economically, he is too pro-free-market for the left (both hard and soft). Socially, he is too conservative for both the left and parts of the center. But he will solidify the mainstream right and may peel off some Le Pen supporters by giving an acceptable face/voice to their concerns. His main advantage may be that he is not Le Pen (and thus socially acceptable) and not socialist (and thus not associated with Hollande's presidency). But he would need to temper his pro-market enthusiasm in order to win.  Le Pen may attract the hard left (who share her economic platform), but may also lose some voters to Fillon as noted above. The critical question is whether there still be a stigma attached to not voting against her in the second round (as against her father in 2002) or not. Also, it depends on whether economic or social issues will dominate voters' decisions (if the former, her chances are stronger). Too early to answer these questions, but these are things to watch as the race develops. How can the Socialists get a chance in this race? After Hollande declined to run, Vals would probably be the party's standard bearer, but even adding his and Hollande's share of the vote in recent polls, he would still be around 18-20 percent, well behind Fillon and Le Pen. But suppose (I) Macron drops out, or (2) Macron runs in the Socialist primaries (rather than as an independent), and wins. Then it would be a three-way race and the Socialist candidate may make it to the second round. The Socialist candidate would be weaker than Le Pen but stronger than Fillon on economic issues, and the other way around on social issues. So he may have a chance to win by playing up social issues against Le Pen and economic issues against Fillon. These are long shots, but they warrant a non-zero probability. Finally, I still keep zero for "None of the above". Independent candidates have traditionally had it hard to get to the second round, Macron's or Melenchon's reasonable poll numbers notwithstanding.

Interesting dog-that-didn't-bark look at Europe from the Washington Post: https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/europe/clintons-loss-is-one-more-nail-in-the-coffin-of-center-left-politics-in-the-west/2016/11/24/44229664-ab3d-11e6-8f19-21a1c65d2043_story.html In the entire article, there is only one reference to immigration - a mention of the "anti-immigrant" UKIP. It seems to me obvious that anti-immigrant sentiment has been simmering in Europe for a long time, and with the deluge of migrants last year the simmering is now about to boil over. If the authors of the article are any indication of "respectable" thinking in Europe, they can't bring themselves to acknowledge this, and their hesitation to see reality will probably cause an electoral shock in France, just as we saw in Britain and the United States. Some quotes: To historians, the unlikely abandonment of this former European bedrock is partly a function of its own achievements.“It was a failure by success,” said Timothy Snyder, a historian of 20th-century Europe at Yale University. “Once the left becomes not revolutionary but transformative, and once that transformation succeeds, people start taking it for granted. “Europeans take for granted that they will have public education, free health care and social services,” he said. “And the left doesn’t get votes on this anymore.” End first quote. Europeans voted to have "public education, free health care and social services" for themselves, not for anybody who happens to make it to their shores. There is no reason for ordinary citizens to accept EU policies and law that require countries to take in asylum seekers and economic migrants, regardless of the social and economic cost. Another quote: "Trump’s victory in the United States rested at least in part on a similar phenomenon — a billionaire tycoon using appeals to xenophobia and racism to scoop up support from voters who no longer believe the party of the working man has their interests at heart." End second quote. Unmentioned is that in the case of the Democrats, at least, the voters may be correct about the party not having their interests at heart. In any case, the authors of the article make no case that the Democrats *do* have working class voters' interests at heart, they merely posit that Trump does not. Of course, Trump may not, but that doesn't mean that the Democrats do. So the question for Europe, and for France specifically, is whether the left parties, (center left or far left) actually represent the interests of working people. Again, it isn't enough to say that the right is scamming the voters (even stipulating that that's true); the real question is whether the voters are correct about the left parties abandoning their interests. If the left parties have abandoned native-born working people, those people have no rational reason to vote for the left parties. The only reasons that left parties can offer are sentimental ones, or attempts at moral blackmail where voters who care about their traditional societies and historic populations are racists. Final quote: One implication of the growing void on Europe’s left could be profound political instability, both within specific countries and geopolitically. Another could be the emergence of a right-wing stranglehold, based on widespread nostalgia for a world that, in Snyder’s view, never actually existed. “All these continental parties are nostalgic for the interwar nation-state, which was a total disaster,” he said. “There was never any moment when they were happy, independent nation-states. There was never such a time, and their nostalgia is a kind of disguise. “If you plunge into that abyss,” he added, “very bad things lie ahead.” End last quote. This gentleman talks as if he is the only person in the world who is conversant with the history of the 20th century. Actually, you can probably make a good case that the problem with tyrannical nationalism in the mid-twentieth century derived from the tyranny, not the nationalism. But never mind; suppose the nationalism was the problem, or at least one component of a larger problem. Why should this be so in the future? The one "argument" that opponents of national parties always make is that the success of such parties means a return to the 1930s. They never say why; they just assume, again, that no one knows a thing about twentieth century history, and if they do, they're just dying to recreate it.  Opponents of national parties are oblivious to the actual grievances of the native populations of Europe, and are completely unwilling to discover what those grievances are, let alone address them. I suppose it is possible that the Republican candidate might win the runoff against Le Pen, but I am more inclined to think that we will get the same kind of surprise we got from Trump and Brexit.

On Wednesday evening, we watched her holding forth on mainstream television news, where she has not been a regular guest. Most journalists have as little sympathy for her as she has for them, and she had been staying out of the public eye over the past 10 months, working hard to build an electoral strategy. During the period between France’s regional elections last December, when her party scored 27 percent of the popular vote but failed to win control of any region, and the presidential election next spring, she has set herself a single goal: to build enough respectability to shatter the so-called republican front through which mainstream parties unite in the second round of a French election to prevent the National Front from winning. Ms. Le Pen, 48, has worked patiently to transform her party from a marginal extremist movement into an organization able to seize and exercise power. Now she needs to ramp up the frustration among French citizens, which has already propelled her to the top of opinion polls ahead of the first round of presidential voting on April 23, into a force powerful enough to break the barrier of conventional politics and push her through to victory in the second round, scheduled for May 7. She is emboldened by Mr. Trump’s upset of Hillary Clinton, which she thinks has significantly enhanced her chances of achieving just that. What the president-elect has done, she said on French public television, has been to “prove that what was presented as impossible can be made possible.” Now she confidently says she believes that it can also happen here — that France in 2017 will provide the third stage of a global political uprising begun by Brexit and reinforced by Mr. Trump’s victory. She is not the only one to believe it. Former Prime Minister Jean-Pierre Raffarin, a respected center-right senator, thinks the news delivered to France by the American election is this: “Marine Le Pen can win.” Just as a Trump candidacy, let alone a victory, was unthinkable a year ago, most French experts had dismissed the possibility of the far-right leader’s winning the Élysée Palace in 2017. Brexit and Mr. Trump have changed that. “This is the people’s choice,” Ms. Le Pen boasts. “If the people deliver so many surprises to the elites,” she said, it is because the elites “are disconnected.” “You don’t draw the right lessons,” she told an interviewer who tried to get her to condemn Mr. Trump’s sexism. “This question is of no interest in the face of this gigantic change.” Ms. Le Pen is walking a fine line. She does not want to be Donald Trump. She is wary of his excesses. She wants to avoid accusations of racism and sexism: that image belonged to her anti-Semitic father, Jean-Marie Le Pen, whom she managed to expel last year from the party he had founded.

Of the four presidential elections held since 1990, three have been contested between the UMP/Republicains and the PS, with the FN reaching the final round in 2002. The National Front's candidate is almost certain to be Marine Le Pen.  The Republicain candidate is highly likely to be one of Francois Fillon, Nicolas Sarkozy or Alain Juppe. The frontrunner is Alain Juppe and Nicolas Sarkozy's ongoing investigation for misuse of funds on top of his unpopularity is likely to do him harm. Alain Juppe therefore looks the strong favourite. For the PS, Francois Hollande is the sitting President but suffers from very low approval ratings on top of ongoing political troubles over workers' rights and security. His former Economy Minister Emmanuel Macron is running as an independent, trying to appeal to the right and the left. Hollande's main challengers are Manuel Valls, Arnaud Montebourg and Martine Aubry. The most likely contests are therefore Le Pen-Macron-Sarkozy-Hollande, Le Pen-Macron-Sarkozy-other PS, Le Pen-Macron-Juppe-Hollande, Le Pen-Macron-Juppe-other PS with relative likelihoods of c.15%, c.15%, c.30%, c.30%. Polling suggests the run offs would then be Le Pen-Sarkozy, Le Pen-Macron/other PS, Le Pen-Juppe and Le Pen-Juppe. In the only past case when the FN reached the run off (2002), other voters combined to give Chirac a 82-18% win. This also took place in the regional elections in 2015, when the FN were defeated in all regions in the second round. Le Pen has therefore a 95% chance of making the final round, but just a 20% chance of beating either a Republicain or PS candidate.  The PS only have a 15% chance of winning because they are unlikely to make the run off even without Hollande. Juppe or Sarkozy are likely to win in any contest they take part in, of which there is an 85% chance. Macron would be favourite in a run-off between himself and Le Pen, which is itself very unlikely.

This question is really several questions in one: Which candidates will be nominated by their respective parties? Which of those candidates will place 1st and 2nd in the first round? Who will win the second round? Of the important parties, only the FN has decided on its candidate (Le Pen). Especially in the Republicans there is a very broad field of contenders and the Socialists could well decide that running Hollande is not in their best interest. Hollande's candidacy is by no means a sure thing (http://www.politico.eu/article/what-frances-unemployment-news-means-for-francois-hollandes-job-french-elections-2017/). An obvious independent contender would be former economy minister Macron (who has renounced his party affiliation with the socialists). None of the Socialists' potential candidates are currently polling well enough to be among the winners of the 1st round. But most candidates are underpolled, so give the party a token 15% chance of winning, subject to change once we know more about the final candidates. The Republicans and FN certainly have candidates strong enough to go into the runoff. I also think that Macron has at least a chance of placing 1st or 2nd in the first round. For the second round, I basically assume that anyone running against Le Pen wins. She is stronger than in past election cycles, but except for Hollande (who won't be able to reach the 2nd round), polling suggests (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_for_the_French_presidential_election,_2017#Opinion_polls_for_expected_second_round_of_voting) that she will loose against any other possible candidate. That leaves the FN with a token 1% chance of winning the election. The big unknown is how Macron would poll against a challenger from the Republicans. This is hard to predict, but I assign him a 15% chance, similarly to the chances of the Socialists. That leaves a 69% chance for the Republicans, in line with the GJ consensus.

The opinion polls indicate that the Republican Parties candidate should win. To lose the Republicans would need to choose a very poor candidate or really screw up the campaign. As in many elections now (for the US President for example) voters vote against the candidate they hate as much as for the candidate they want. The NF seems to have strong support in 27% to 39% range, for the first round but in a second round the only candidate that would risk losing to Le Pen would be Hollande. Hollande seems so unpopular that unless the Republicans pick a really poor candidate he would not get into the second round. It appears that the NF are extremely likely to get the second round. So the logical thing for each of the other parties to do would be to choose the candidate that can most certainly beat her. The socialists will find it difficult to find such a candidate, the Republicans have several who appear to be likely to beat Le Pen; Juppe seems to be more popular (or less unpopular) than Sarkozy.  There is a chance that Macron could win, but the opinion polls that suggested he would do well assumed that he would be a candidate for the Socialists, he has now said he hopes to stand for a centerist party. Political parties in France seem to be much more  like the personal team of a politician and rise and fall with their leaders, than the more institutional permanent political parties in most other countries. (The politicians are bigger than the parties in France.) So its not clear if breaking with the unpopular PS of Hollande would befit or harm Macron. Maybe he is too new to have as many voters hate him as hate the other candidates.
